principles.label: Competence Principle
principles.definition: Engineers shall perform services only in areas where they possess adequate education, training, and experience
principles.manifestation_in_case: Engineer A demonstrated environmental engineering competence but lacked experience with AI tools
principles.source_text: Engineer A, an environmental engineer with several years of experience

principles.label: Direction and Control Principle
principles.definition: Engineers shall not affix signatures to documents not prepared under their direction and control
principles.manifestation_in_case: Question of whether AI-generated documents were under Engineer A's direction and control
principles.source_text: Engineer A did not cite their use of AI-software or its large language models

principles.label: Quality Assurance Principle
principles.definition: Professional work products should be verified for accuracy and compliance before delivery
principles.manifestation_in_case: Engineer A conducted thorough review of report but only cursory review of designs
principles.source_text: Engineer A conducted a thorough review of the report, cross-checking key facts

principles.label: Transparency Principle
principles.definition: Engineers should be forthright about methods, tools, and significant contributors to their work
principles.manifestation_in_case: Engineer A did not disclose use of AI tools to Client W
principles.source_text: Engineer A did not cite their use of AI-software or its large language models

principles.label: Client Confidentiality Principle
principles.definition: Engineers shall treat client information as confidential and not disclose without consent
principles.manifestation_in_case: Uploading client data to open-source AI software may expose confidential information
principles.source_text: gathered the relevant information provided by Client W and relied on the AI software
